citation: Young, Michael D. 1996. “Cognitive Mapping Meets Semantic Networks.” Journal of Conflict Resolution 40(3): 395-414.
annotation: Young introduces WorldView, a computer-assisted content-analysis and modeling system that merges cognitive mapping with the symbol-based formalism of semantic networks.  By enlarging the repertoire of representable relationships (truth-values, temporal and modal modifiers, differentiated links, action predicates) and by adding structural and comparative metrics, WorldView enables richer descriptions of belief systems and supplies manipulable semantic-network data structures for process models of reasoning and policy choice.

vocabulary.definition: A method for modeling and studying the beliefs and decision processes that guide actors’ behaviour by representing concepts and causal links among them.
vocabulary.source_context: “Since its introduction in the early 1970s … cognitive mapping has been available to model and study the beliefs and decision processes that ultimately lead to state behavior.”

vocabulary.definition: A symbol-based knowledge representation scheme comprising nodes (concepts) and labeled links (relations) connecting them.
vocabulary.source_context: “WorldView, which uses the symbol-based formalism of semantic networks.”

vocabulary.definition: Young’s computer-based tool that integrates cognitive mapping with semantic-network techniques to extract, aggregate, and analyse belief structures.
vocabulary.source_context: “The purpose of this article is to present a new computer-based tool for enhanced cognitive mapping—WorldView.”

vocabulary.definition: The organised set of propositions, concepts, and relationships that together form an actor’s worldview.
vocabulary.source_context: “…necessary for modelling belief structures and supporting process models of decision making.”

vocabulary.definition: The substantive ideas (concepts and propositions) contained within an actor’s belief structure.
vocabulary.source_context: “WorldView provides important advantages … assists in the systematic study of belief system content.”

vocabulary.definition: The sequence of cognitive operations through which an actor moves from perceptions and beliefs to choice.
vocabulary.source_context: “…and decision process.”

vocabulary.definition: A representational approach that uses meaningful symbols (e.g., is-a, part-of) rather than numeric values to label relations in a network.
vocabulary.source_context: “…uses the symbol-based formalism of semantic networks.”

vocabulary.definition: A square matrix that records the presence (1) or absence (0) of a link between every pair of concepts in a cognitive map.
vocabulary.source_context: “Each cognitive map is represented by an adjacency matrix, a square matrix with a row and column for each concept…”

vocabulary.definition: Branch of graph theory dealing with nodes connected by ordered (directional) edges, used to formalise cognitive maps.
vocabulary.source_context: “…advantage of a correspondence between directed graph theory and matrix mathematics.”

vocabulary.definition: Use of matrix algebra techniques for manipulating adjacency matrices that represent cognitive maps.
vocabulary.source_context: “…correspondence between directed graph theory and matrix mathematics.”

vocabulary.definition: A directional link indicating that a change in one concept produces change in another; coded as positive (+) or negative (−) in traditional maps.
vocabulary.source_context: “Cognitive mapping procedures treat concepts as nodes … with either positive (+) or negative (−) causal relationships as the connections.”

vocabulary.definition: A causal link specifying that an increase in the source concept increases the target concept.
vocabulary.source_context: “…positive (+) or negative (−) causal relationships…”

vocabulary.definition: A causal link specifying that an increase in the source concept decreases the target concept.
vocabulary.source_context: “…positive (+) or negative (−) causal relationships…”

vocabulary.definition: A proposition containing more than one embedded clause or relational assertion, posing difficulties for simple causal mapping.
vocabulary.source_context: “The inability of cognitive mapping to handle compound statements can be illustrated…”

vocabulary.definition: In WorldView, a treated relationship elevated to the status of a node so it can itself be the subject or object of other relations.
vocabulary.source_context: “…if relationships are elevated from labelled connections to nodes in their own right…”

vocabulary.definition: A tag (past, present, future, goal, hypothetical, normative) that qualifies when or in what mode a relationship holds.
vocabulary.source_context: “To capture information about when a statement holds true, six relationship modifiers—past, present, future, goal, hypothetical, and normative—were developed.”

vocabulary.definition: Designation (true, false, partial, possible, impossible) indicating an actor’s asserted certainty about a proposition.
vocabulary.source_context: “To capture these negations, truth-values were developed…

vocabulary.definition: Marks a relationship as pertaining to a completed or historical state of affairs.
vocabulary.source_context: “A past relationship modifier indicates that the relationship referred to is in the past.”

vocabulary.definition: Marks a relationship as currently holding or an action as ongoing.
vocabulary.source_context: “A present relationship modifier indicates that the action is ongoing or that the indicated relationship currently holds.”

vocabulary.definition: Marks a relationship as expected to hold at some future time.
vocabulary.source_context: “The future relationship modifier is used to represent statements that the actor believes will be true at some future point in time.”

vocabulary.definition: Marks a proposition as expressing something the actor desires to bring about.
vocabulary.source_context: “A goal relationship modifier indicates that the author of the text wants the statement to become true.”

vocabulary.definition: Marks a proposition as conditional or speculative (if-then reasoning).
vocabulary.source_context: “The hypothetical relationship modifier is used to capture hypothetico-deductive reasoning.”

vocabulary.definition: Marks a proposition as reflecting an ideal, obligation, or evaluative judgement rather than an operational goal.
vocabulary.source_context: “The normative relationship modifier indicates that the relationship is normatively valued.”

vocabulary.definition: Indicates the speaker believes the statement holds universally for the referenced class or instance.
vocabulary.source_context: “The true truth-value indicates that the statement is true…”

vocabulary.definition: Indicates the speaker asserts the statement does not hold for any referenced instance.
vocabulary.source_context: “The false truth-value indicates that the statement is not true…”

vocabulary.definition: Marks a statement as true for some but not all members of a class.
vocabulary.source_context: “The partial truth-value is a qualified indication of truth…”

vocabulary.definition: Indicates a statement could become true at some time; includes capability assertions.
vocabulary.source_context: “A possible truth-value indicates that the statement could become true…”

vocabulary.definition: Marks a statement as incapable of ever becoming true.
vocabulary.source_context: “An impossible truth-value indicates that the statement cannot become true at any time.”

vocabulary.definition: WorldView feature allowing analysts to collapse different lexical items into a single concept node for analysis.
vocabulary.source_context: “The synonym facility allows analysis to determine whether varying the inclusiveness of synonyms will result in different political choices.”

vocabulary.definition: The capability of WorldView to combine data from several documents or respondents into a single composite cognitive map.
vocabulary.source_context: “…provides aggregation over texts or subject responses…”

vocabulary.definition: Structural metric reflecting the proportion of bridge relations, indicating how vertically organised the map is.
vocabulary.source_context: “Dependency reflects the number of pathways … over which it is possible to travel to concepts…”

vocabulary.definition: A relationship through which only one path leads to a concept, making that link critical.
vocabulary.source_context: “If only one relationship leads to a concept, that relationship is defined as a bridge.”

vocabulary.definition: Structural metric capturing how interrelated the concepts are, based on ratio of links to nodes.
vocabulary.source_context: “Connectedness reflects the number of relationships between concepts in the cognitive map…”

vocabulary.definition: The count of distinct concept nodes in a cognitive map.
vocabulary.source_context: “Size is the number of concepts in the cognitive map.”

vocabulary.definition: Structural metric operationalised as the standard deviation of relationship salience values across the map.
vocabulary.source_context: “Uniformity of salience reflects the firmness with which each component belief is held…”

vocabulary.definition: A numeric count of how often a unique relationship occurs in the data set, used as a strength indicator.
vocabulary.source_context: “Salience is measured by counting how often a belief is expressed…”

vocabulary.definition: Comparative procedure for identifying identical, divergent, and unique concepts when two cognitive maps are matched.
vocabulary.source_context: “Concept comparison is … indicates which particular concepts are in both maps and have identical relationships…”

vocabulary.definition: Quantitative index of change based on the minimum number of additions/deletions required to convert one map into another.
vocabulary.source_context: “…transformation cost provides an indicator of change in cognitive maps that measures the amount of change…”

vocabulary.definition: Discrete change operation of adding a new link between two concepts during transformation cost calculation.
vocabulary.source_context: “(a) Relationship-addition: the creation of a relational link between two concepts.”

vocabulary.definition: Discrete change operation of removing an existing link.
vocabulary.source_context: “(b) Relationship-deletion: the removal of a relational link…”

vocabulary.definition: Discrete change operation representing a unit change in strength of an existing link.
vocabulary.source_context: “(c) Relationship salience increase or decrease: a unit change in the strength…”

vocabulary.definition: Discrete change operation of removing a node (and its incident links) from the map.
vocabulary.source_context: “(d) Concept-deletion: the removal of a concept. Concept-deletion requires that all connecting relationships are deleted.”

vocabulary.definition: Discrete change operation of inserting a new node, usually accompanied by new links.
vocabulary.source_context: “(e) Concept-addition: the creation of a new node that reflects the addition of new information…”

vocabulary.definition: Comparative metric combining transformation cost and concept overlap to capture substantive differences between two maps over time.
vocabulary.source_context: “Incongruence is expected to have a relatively high value for maps that precede large changes in behaviour.”

vocabulary.definition: Search mechanism that propagates activation from one node to adjacent nodes to retrieve related information.
vocabulary.source_context: “Directed-walk uses spreading activation to generate the definition of the situation…”

vocabulary.definition: A reasoning model implemented by Young that traverses the WorldView network using a salience heuristic.
vocabulary.source_context: “One such model, directed-walk, is modelled on the cognitive process model of Bonham and his colleagues.”

vocabulary.definition: Decision rule in which the proposition with the highest salience is selected for processing during reasoning.
vocabulary.source_context: “The salience heuristic uses the strength of a proposition in a belief system to direct memory search.”

vocabulary.definition: Psychological theory viewing memory as a network of concepts linked by associations; complementary to semantic networks.
vocabulary.source_context: “Techniques from semantic network research were chosen … complementary to the associative network model of memory (Estes 1991).”

vocabulary.definition: Method in which trained coders identify and classify units of meaning in texts according to a coding scheme.
vocabulary.source_context: “The first function of WorldView … is accomplished with a human-coded content analysis system.”

vocabulary.term: relationship-type list (equal, condition, component, preference/greater-than, if-then, possess, attribute, location, is-a, strategy, know, warrant-for)
vocabulary.definition: Catalogue of specific relational predicates WorldView recognises for coding interconcept links beyond causal ones.
vocabulary.source_context: “Table 1 WorldView Coding Categories – Relationships.”

vocabulary.term: action-type list (accept, allow, assert, assist, attack, cause, confront, consult, control, cooperate, decide, defend, delay, enforce, enhance, feel, honour, ignore, influence, intervene, invade, lead, limit, lose, maintain, meet, monitor, negotiate, open, order, organise, perform, propose, purchase, ratify, reduce, release, restore, share, sign, stop, support, threaten, use, verify, visit, vote-on, withdraw, yield-to)
vocabulary.definition: Set of verbs constituting WorldView’s coding categories for agent actions/events used in mapping belief structures.
vocabulary.source_context: “Table 1 WorldView Coding Categories – Actions.”

vocabulary.definition: Logical connectors used in WorldView to represent joint actions (and) or alternative sets (or) within compound concepts.
vocabulary.source_context: “In addition … the WorldView system also recognises two conjunctions, and and or…”

vocabulary.definition: String-editing distance metric inspiring transformation-cost computation for cognitive maps.
vocabulary.source_context: “Transformation cost is similar to a Levenshtein measure of difference (Kruskal 1983)…”
